title: Goals and Actions
text:
As part of the CCSPP application and implementation process, schools are expected to prioritize the key topics, goals, and challenges identified in their Needs and Assets Assessment. Grantees were asked to submit three goals associated with their CCSPP implementation and in line with the California Community Schools Framework and the Whole Child and Family Supports Inventory. There were a total of (5,254 goals) submitted in total across 1,920 grantees.
The top categories across all goals submitted were:

Social-Emotional Well-Being & Mental Health: Provide consistent access to school-based mental health support through structured referral and service delivery systems. / Positive and Restorative School Climate Increase Student Social Emotional Learning (SEL) Wellness
Attendance & Absenteeism Reduction: Reduce chronic absenteeism through early detection systems, and monthly attendance-focused family workshops.
Family & Community Engagement: There will be a monthly engagement of each group (students, staff, families and community partners) that centers community school work.
Academic Achievement & Student Learning: Increase student academic achievement by strengthening tutoring and specialist intervention systems.
School Climate & Shared Leadership: Implement a positive and restorative school climate
Community School Framework & Whole-School Implementation: To create community Schools Team that center the voices of students, families and community;
Integrated Student Supports: Fill gaps in integrated support services for students

Grantees were also asked to submit a metric associated with each school-specific goal. The most common metric selected was Other locally developed metric, which was selected for about a third of all goals submitted. Other common metrics included chronic absenteeism rates, climate measures and proficiency scores. Within the category of other local measures, some common metrics were: [add analysis here].

title: Capacity Building Strategies
text:
Overview of Capacity Building Strategies in Year 3
Overall, Year 3 APR data indicates that Strategic Community Partnership has 14%, the highest percentage of grantees with a self rating of being in the Transforming phase, compared to other Capacity Building Strategies. For three Capacity Building Strategies- Sustaining Staff and Resources, Strategic Community Partnerships, and Collaborative Leadership, there are more schools identifying as Engaging than Visioning. For Shared Commitment, Understanding, and Priorities, and Centering Community-Based Learning, there are more grantees in the Visioning phase than the Engaging phase.



Capacity Building Strategies: Year 1-3 Trends
A closer look at Cohort 1 schools (Cohort 1 in Year 1 = 450 Schools; Cohort 1 in Year 2 = 431 Schools; Cohort 1 in Year 3 = 435 Schools) across the three years of implementation reveal several trends. There is an overall trend of grantees moving from Visioning to Engaging, and from Engaging to Transforming over the three years. Cohort 1 grantees have achieved great successes in several capacity building strategies. Nearly one in three Cohort 1 grantees (32.4%) self-reported as being in the Transforming phase in Strategic Community Leadership. The percentage of grantees in Visioning have decreased significantly. For instance, while 62% of grantees considered themselves still in Visioning phase in Year 1, this percentage lowered to only 27.4% in Year 3 for Centering Community-Based Learning.

Shared Commitment, Understanding and PrioritiesCentering Community-Based LearningCollaborative LeadershipStrategic Community PartnershipsSustaining Staff and Resources

title: Engaging Educational Partners
text:
Overview of Engaging Educational Partners in Year 3
Analysis of Year 3 APR data indicates that schools were most successful in engaging administrators (89.7% at 75-100% engagement rate), certified staff (58.2% at 75-100% engagement rate), and classified staff (44.2% at 75-100% engagement rate). More than 60% of respondents also reported engaging 75-100% of community partners. Despite 6% of grantees indicate a 0% engagement rate of students, longitudinal trends of Y1 through Y3 showed that students engaged at 0% has dropped to the lowest in Year 3 from previous two years (see below).

For Internal Use only, some of these groups are very high in NAs, which means many respondents did not fill it out. This is something our recent revisions (e.g., removed Community Members as a reporting category; added the definition of Community Partners) can help address in the upcoming year.

Engaging Educational Partners: Y1-Y3 Trends
In Cohort 1 schools, we see steady increases in the percentage of grantees that reported engaging each group of stakeholders at 75-100% each year. Year 3 APR shows particularly enhanced engagement of community partners, which increased by 40 percentage points.

The following two graphs break the results down by groups of stakeholders, and showcase longitudinal trends of engaging students and community partners. Compared to previous years, the percentage of Cohort 1 grantees that reported engaging students and community partners at 0% dropped to the lowest in Year 3. Compared to Year 2, fewer Cohort 1 grantees in Year 3 reported engaging students at 25-74%. For student engagement, grantees moved from these middle categories to a lower (1-24%) or a higher engagement level (75-100%). For community partners engagement, the majority of Cohort 1 grantees moved up to the highest (75%) engagement level.

StudentsCommunity Partners











Historically Marginalized Groups
In Year 3, more than half of grantees reported engaging 75-100% of foster youth and racially marginalized students. However, foster youth and students experiencing homelessness are two groups where the highest percentage of grantees reported 0% engagement.

title: Home Page
text:
Annual Progress Report (APR)
These visualizations reflect the data from the CCSPP APR for school sites for the 2022-2023 school year, the 2023-2024 school year and initial findings from the 2024-2025 school for the Capacity Building Strategies.
The APR serves as a tool to assess implementation efforts, and to encourage reflection as part of an ongoing continuous improvement process. It was designed to be developed by each schools CCSPP shared decision-making team or council to ensure participation from students, staff, families and community partners. The report is intended to align with required annual update presentations on community school planning, including data and outcomes from the prior year at each school site.
The APR is aligned with the California Community Schools Framework and also aligns with resources provided by the State Transformational Assistance Center (S-TAC) including the Community Schools Implementation Plan Template, the Community Schools Needs and Assets Assessment (NAA) Guide, and the Capacity Building Strategies: A Developmental Rubric, that are available for optional use by grantees.
Select specific report by clicking on the section above.

Reports are reflective of the data aggregated by Region.
